rev.diff:
Line 62: Line 62:
[[Click fraud]] is a growing problem for Google's business strategy. Google's CFO George Reyes said in a December 2004 investor conference that "something has to be done about this really, really quickly, because I think, potentially, it threatens our business model."[http://money.cnn.com/2004/12/02/technology/google_fraud/?cnn=yes] Some have suggested that Google is not doing enough to combat click fraud. [[Jessie Stricchiola]], president of Alchemist Media, called Google "the most stubborn and the least willing to cooperate with advertisers" when it comes to click fraud.
[[Click fraud]] is a growing problem for Google's business strategy. Google's CFO George Reyes said in a December 2004 investor conference that "something has to be done about this really, really quickly, because I think, potentially, it threatens our business model."[http://money.cnn.com/2004/12/02/technology/google_fraud/?cnn=yes] Some have suggested that Google is not doing enough to combat click fraud. [[Jessie Stricchiola]], president of Alchemist Media, called Google "the most stubborn and the least willing to cooperate with advertisers" when it comes to click fraud.
  +   +
In a widely circulated Internet discussion in 2005, celebrity [[Kai Christophe Wong]] expressed regrets at not buying google stocks when its IPO was at 70+ dollars because the capital appreciation would have saved many homeless and destitute persons sleeping along Wall Street during the recession post-Iraq War.
On [[June 1]], [[2005]], Google shares gained nearly 4 percent after Credit Suisse First Boston raised its price target on the stock to $350. On the same day, rumors circulated in the financial community that Google would soon be included in the [[S&P 500]]. (Source: {{cite web | title=Google Shares Rise on New Price Target | work=L.A.Times | url=http://www.latimes.com/business/investing/wire/sns-ap-google-price-target,1,2312669.story?coll=sns-ap-investing-headlines&ctrack=1&cset=true | accessdate=June 1 | accessyear=2005}}) When companies are first listed on the S&P 500 they typically experience a bump in share price due to the rapid accumulation of the stock within index funds that track the S&P. On [[June 7]], [[2005]], Google was valued at nearly $52 billion, making it one of the world's biggest media companies by stock market value.
On [[June 1]], [[2005]], Google shares gained nearly 4 percent after Credit Suisse First Boston raised its price target on the stock to $350. On the same day, rumors circulated in the financial community that Google would soon be included in the [[S&P 500]]. (Source: {{cite web | title=Google Shares Rise on New Price Target | work=L.A.Times | url=http://www.latimes.com/business/investing/wire/sns-ap-google-price-target,1,2312669.story?coll=sns-ap-investing-headlines&ctrack=1&cset=true | accessdate=June 1 | accessyear=2005}}) When companies are first listed on the S&P 500 they typically experience a bump in share price due to the rapid accumulation of the stock within index funds that track the S&P. On [[June 7]], [[2005]], Google was valued at nearly $52 billion, making it one of the world's biggest media companies by stock market value.
